responses: Make sure to use strong, unique passwords for each account. A good password is typically at least 12-15 characters long and includes a mix of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols. Avoid using personal details like birthdays or common words.
A strong password is your first line of defense! Consider using a password manager to help you create and store complex, unique passwords for all your accounts.
For password safety, enable two-factor authentication (2FA) wherever possible. This adds an extra layer of security beyond just your password.

responses: Be cautious of emails, messages, or calls asking for personal information or immediate payment. Scammers often disguise themselves as trusted organizations like banks or government agencies.
Never click on suspicious links or download attachments from unknown senders. Always verify the sender's identity through a separate, trusted channel if you're unsure.
If an offer seems too good to be true, it probably is. Be wary of urgent requests, threats, or high-pressure tactics designed to make you act without thinking.
Phishing tip: Look out for generic greetings (Dear Customer), poor grammar, and urgent calls to action in emails. Hover over links to see the actual URL before clicking.

responses: Regularly review the privacy settings on your social media accounts and other online services to control who sees your information.
Be mindful of the information you share online. Even seemingly harmless details can be pieced together by malicious actors.
Consider using a Virtual Private Network (VPN) for an extra layer of privacy, especially when using public Wi-Fi networks.
